title: Perforated Peptic Ulcer
diagnosis_topic: Full-thickness gastric or duodenal ulcer resulting in peritonitis
setup_script: “A 50-year-old man with a history of NSAID use presents with sudden, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back. He appears acutely ill and his abdomen is rigid. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “You note board-like rigidity with diffuse rebound tenderness and absent bowel sounds.”
“WBC 18 K/µL, lactate 4 mmol/L, hemoglobin within normal range.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident requests upright chest or abdominal X-ray
dynamic_flow.reply: “Free air is seen under the diaphragm.”
“CT confirms pneumoperitoneum with free fluid and no evidence of localized containment.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics with NG decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient stabilizes slightly with fluids and NG decompression in place.”
“The patient develops worsening hypotension and confusion, consistent with progressing sepsis.”
“You bring the patient emergently to the operating room. Please describe your operative approach.”
“You perform laparoscopic exploration and identify a 1 cm perforation on the anterior duodenal bulb. What are your next operative steps?”
“You perform a midline laparotomy. The same 1 cm perforation is identified. What operative steps will you perform?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs Graham patch repair
dynamic_flow.reply: “You complete an omental patch repair with peritoneal irrigation. The patient stabilizes intraoperatively.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not describe operative details fully
dynamic_flow.reply: “Please describe the steps of the repair, including preparation, patch placement, and closure.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident does not address antibiotic coverage or postoperative care
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient is extubated postoperatively. What additional postoperative management will you provide?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident addresses H. pylori and ulcer prevention
dynamic_flow.reply: “PPI therapy is initiated. H. pylori testing is pending. What follow-up counseling will you provide to this patient?”
“In what scenario would nonoperative management be considered for perforated ulcer disease?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of perforated viscus from exam and imaging
Timely resuscitation with IV fluids, antibiotics, and NG decompression
Decision to proceed with operative management
Appropriate operative strategy (laparoscopic vs. open, Graham patch repair)
Ability to describe operative details (omentum mobilization, defect closure, irrigation)
Consideration of postoperative PPI therapy and H. pylori eradication
Understanding of indications and limitations of nonoperative management

resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by rapidly identifying perforated peptic ulcer based on history, exam, and imaging. Your prioritization of resuscitation and surgical intervention showed good clinical judgment. Communication of your management plan was structured and clear.Areas for Improvement:A more detailed description of operative steps, including omental patch technique, would strengthen your performance.
